questions.question_text:
A penetration test is being scoped for a set of web services with API endpoints. The APIs will be hosted on existing web application servers. Some of the new
APIs will be available to unauthenticated users, but some will only be available to authenticated users. Which of the following tools or activities would the penetration tester MOST likely use or do during the engagement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: i agree with noto21, its B & E
Im having a hard time with BC. BE would be what i go with. Proxy as the tool but recon as the activity

comments.content: I think you may be right. But maybe a port scanner could tell you what web services are running, and knowing that, maybe you could figure out the APIs?
What will an intercepting proxy tell us? Will that just tell us what is being sent to the API endpoints? If the pentester is testing those API endpoints, wouldn't the pentester already know?

questions.question_text:
A recent overview of the network's security and storage applications reveals a large amount of data that needs to be isolated for security reasons. Below are the critical applications and devices configured on the network:
✑ Firewall
✑ Core switches
✑ RM server
✑ Virtual environment
✑ NAC solution
The security manager also wants data from all critical applications to be aggregated to correlate events from multiple sources. Which of the following must be configured in certain applications to help ensure data aggregation and data isolation are implemented on the critical applications and devices? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: The key from the statement is «...requirements analysis and risk assessment» and «... The new system will replace ...» Just one answer talk about requeriments. So B.

Maybe: D. Design reviews and user acceptance testing to ensure the system has been deployed properly ? 
I don't see any problem with the given answer. But this answer also seems to make sense.

comments.content: It's in the development process. It hasn't been deployed yet.
The amount of shit you post is stifiling.

questions.question_text:
As part of the development process for a new system, the organization plans to perform requirements analysis and risk assessment. The new system will replace a legacy system, which the organization has used to perform data analytics.
Which of the following is MOST likely to be part of the activities conducted by management during this phase of the project?

choices.D: Design reviews and user acceptance testing to ensure the system has been deployed properly
choices.E: Regression testing to evaluate interoperability with the legacy system during the deployment
choices.A: Static code analysis and peer review of all application code
choices.C: Load testing the system to ensure response times is acceptable to stakeholders
choices.B: Validation of expectations relating to system performance and security

discussion.content: you can do network segmentation in a zero-trust mode way. So, answer D.

comments.content: The question also makes it clear the solutions "do not require additional resources." Again, there is already a host firewall on the endpoint. Just configure that. Why go crazy with complicated network segmentation schemes.

Host based firewalls are not hard to come by. I think most modern OSes have them pre-installed, or at least very easy to get.
I think any of the answers would probably work. But the question makes it clear they want to "block communication" that is exactly what a firewall is designed to do.

discussion.content: Answer D: Network Segmentation - implementing independent VLANs that cannot route to each other will (in theory) block endpoints located in one VLAN from communicating with endpoints in the other, assuming Layer 2 devices, not Layer 3. However, I think the key to this questions is that it asks how to isolate data in ways that do not require additional resources. It can be assumed from the question that we’d have to procure/config/set-up a firewall if we picked that answer.

comments.content: Yes it will... you separate by vlan and don’t allow routing between clans... host firewall would be almost impossible. You’d have to put in a new rule to block each pc you don’t want to give it access to. (Or vice versa to allow) . Answer is D.

Absolutely and completely wrong.
Every host in a VLAN will be able to talk to every other host in a VLAN, *even without a default gateway programmed into the host or available on the subnet*. That's how VLANs and Subnets work (please go check with an actual network admin if you think I'm wrong). A Host based firewall only needs a couple rules, and could be centrally managed from an EPO server. You allow traffic to/from the gateway and authorized intranet and internet servers, and let your explicit deny at the bottom of the firewall rule list block all other communication, which of course INCLUDES all other hosts on your subnet.

I think the part that reads "One recommendation is to block communication between endpoint PCs" is there to throw us off. This doesn't even seem like a good recommendation here. If you remove that sentence and read the question as "...must improve its network security posture in ways that do not require additional resources to implement data isolation. Which of the following would be the BEST solution?" network segmentation makes better sense.

EDR is an additional resource/solution that the organization would have to acquire, which the question says is NOT an option. EDR isn't even an isolation solution.

Now, IF we were looking into how to implement the given recommendation of blocking communication between endpoint PCs, then B could be an option. But this is NOT what the question is asking for.

Note: B. Configuring **a** host-based firewall 
Maybe it's just bad wording. But wouldn't you have to configure the host firewalls on the *all* the endpoints? Not just *a* host-based firewall.

D is correct as they are trying to block communication between the merged companies.
so keeping each company in its own vlan won't allow the traffic

discussion.content:
B
It's not D. D will not block communication between endpoint PCs.

questions.question_text: An organization just merged with an organization in another legal jurisdiction and must improve its network security posture in ways that do not require additional resources to implement data isolation. One recommendation is to block communication between endpoint PCs. Which of the following would be the BEST solution?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
In these determinations, you go with the highest classification in each area for the data types involved. Only concerned with PII, Proprietary and Financial. Of those 3, the highest in Confidentiality is “High” and the highest in Availability is “Medium”. So, the answer is B.
Im going with D, you ONLY need to concentrate on Pll/financial/Proprietary......

PII /financial /Proprietary the three lines shows D high integrity low availability
B is wrong, because. availablility is two low one medium. so it should be totally low

I think the given answer is correct. Remember that we're only looking at PII, financial, and proprietary. Process of elimination, using the highest level in each category of those three specifications, means only B can be true.
The OVERALL classification is high for both confidentiality and availability. So the best choice is A.
Is there a standard formula for calculating this? I could not find one.

comments.content:
It's the highest classification for each category.
Confidentiality is "high" because of PII
Availability is "medium" because of Proprietary

Note: if Financial was "high" for Availability, then the overall classification would be "high" for Availability.
The question only asks for controls for PII, financial, and proprietary data. You can essentially exclude competitive and industrial control profiles from your assessment.

Shouldn't it be high, high
"high" because of PII
"high" because of industrial
???
